module.p: saoil think, wonder, suppose, deem, conceive, imagine, consider, believe is a stative verb with verbal noun saoilsinn fem. or saoiltinn fem. (saoileachdainn? GV: 130)
saoil can take a complement clause introduced by the verb particle gun think/suppose that ...

The most common usage is the future independent first person singular saoilidh mi, eg.
Saoilidh mi gu bheil thu stampail. I think you’re cute. Note that this usage denotes an ongoing present state rather than a specifically future situation.
Saoilidh mi gu robh Brian air beòshlaint na b’ fheàrr a dhèanamh mar chleasaiche.
I think that Brian would have made a better living as an actor. td. 51
Ach saoilidh mi gum feumar eadar-dhealachadh a dhèanamh eadar na dhà.
But I think that we must differentiate between the two. td. 67
Saoileam gu bheil mòran den airgead a’ dol do na daoine ceàrr.
I think that a lot of the money is going to the wrong people. td. 87 Note that saoilidh mi is sometimes found written as saoileam.

Equivalent states in the past are expressed as shaoil mi, etc.
Shaoil mi gun robh thu pòsta. I thought you were married.
Shaoil mi gun d’ fhuair an gille faochadh. Thug mi dha £50 agus cha b’ urrainn duine a bhith cho taingeil.
I thought that the boy was relieved. I gave him £50 and no man could ever be as grateful. td. 49
Choinnich e ri Elsie May aon oidhche ann an taigh-seinnse anns a’ bhaile mhòr, agus shaoil sinn gun deach an dithis a dhèanamh dha a chèile.
He met Elsie May one night in a pub in the city, and we thought that the two of them were made for each other. td. 26
Bha i ceud bliadhna a dh’ aois is esan dhà air fhichead. Cha robh e ach mìos no dhà a-mach ás an oilthigh. Bha a nighean a’ fuireachd còmhla rithe. Bha ise ceithir fichead. Shaoil e gu robh a’ chailleach ann an dòigh na bu shunndaiche na a nighean. [...]
She was a hundred years old and him twenty two. He was just a month or two out of the university. Her daughter was living with her. She was eighty. He thought that the old woman was in a way livelier than her daughter. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Conditional examples –
Bha Uisdean air leth ealanta a’ cluiche air cairtean. Shaoileadh duine gu robh na cairtean a’ tighinn beò na làmhan.
Hugh was exceptionally talented at playing cards. One would think that the cards were coming alive in his hands. td. 54
shaoilinn gun còrdadh iad ris a h-uile duine
I would imagine they would please everybody td. 500

The corresponding negative forms have saoil nach ... eg.
Saoilidh mi nach eil thu thu stampail. I think you aren’t cute. / I don’t think you’re cute.
Shaoil mi nach robh thu thu pòsta. I thought you weren’t married. / I didn’t think you were married.

p.ed: Negative? Saoilidh mi nach eil ... or Cha shaoil mi gu bheil ... ?

shaoileadh tu air Dàibhidh gur h-esan am maraiche as fheàrr air an t-saoghal you would think by (looking at / listening to) David that he was the best seaman in the world [CM: 500]

cha shaoilinn gum biodh mòran sam bith den t-seòrsa seo I shouldn’t think there would be many of this type [CM: 500]
is dòcha gu saoilear nach eil annas mòr ri lorg anns a’ chuspair sin it will probably be thought that there is nothing very interesting to be found in that subject [CM: 500]
shaoil leis he thought [CM: 500]
shaoileam gun cuala mi fuaim air taobh a-muigh uinneag mo ruim I thought I heard a noise outside my room window [CM: 500]
Shaoil leam gum biodh e anns an eaglais an-diugh. I thought that he would be at church today. [GV: 87]
’s ann a shaoiliste le coimhead orra gun robh iad ... one would think to look at them that they were ... [CM: 500]
’S ann a shaoiliste le coimhead orra gun robh iad air a bhith ann o thoiseach tìme. It woud be thought, by looking at them, that they had been there since the beginning of time. [GV 106]
saoilteadh (dialectal saoiliste) it would be thought, one would think, suppose, imagine

bi a’ saoilsinn gun ... –
Bha i a’ saoilsinn gun robh eadhon na craobhan agus na flùraichan a’ cur fàilte oirre. She thought that even the trees and the flowers were welcoming her. [GV 87]

Dè a ... saoil thu ... de ... ? –
dè a shaoil thu den dhealbh-chluich? what did you think of the play? [CM: 500]
innis dè a shaoil thu den sgeulachd say what you thought of the story [CM: 500]
Dè tha thu a’ saoilsinn de na h-atharraichean seo? What do you think of these changes? [GV 87]
Dè tha thu a’ saoiltinn dheth? What do you think of it? [GV: 93]
dè a shaoil thu den dhealbh-chluich? what did you think of the play? [CM: 500]
innis dè a shaoil thu den sgeulachd say what you thought of the story [CM: 500]
saoil mhòran dhe admire [CM: 500]
bha i a’ saoilsinn mòran dheth she admired him [CM: 500]

No subject –
saoil dè thachair do Sheumas? I wonder what happened to James? [CM: 500]
... ach saoil an atharraich e ... ? but do you suppose he’ll change? [CM: 500]
saoil a bheil e deiseil fhathast? do you think he’s ready yet? [CM: 500]
saoil(ibh) am bi stoirm ann? do you think there’ll be a storm? I wonder if there’ll be a storm. [CM: 500]

With pronoun –
saoil sibh a-nis nach bu chòir bacadh a chur air a bhith a’ cumail bheathaichean ann am bogsaichean mar seo? don’t you think now that a stop should be put to keeping animals in boxes like this?
càite, saoil thu, an deach e an uair sin? where, do you think, did he go then? [CM: 500]
